sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our study of 249 CEOs supports the prediction that CEOs’ political ideologies are manifested in companies’ actions and priorities. In this initial demonstration of the theoretical and practical significance of executive political ideology, we have examined its links to CSR practices and, secondarily, corporate PAC allocations. As we discuss below, however, one can readily envision additional organizational domains in which this largely unexplored executive attribute might be consequential, including effects on company performance.

Our project serves to reintroduce the importance of executive values to upper echelons research, and it contributes to the broader discussion about the extent to which corporate executives inject their personal values into corporate decisions. Our results suggest that CEOs are not merely technical optimizers, as neoclassical economics might envision; nor are CEOs uniform in the ways they try to bend their companies to suit themselves, as agency theory generally suggests. Instead, CEOs vary in their preferences, or values, and these differences give rise to heterogeneous firm outcomes.

Although Hambrick and Mason (1984) initially emphasized the role of executive values, almost all subsequent upper echelons studies have examined the effects of other executive attributes, especially executives’ experiences and personality, on organizational outcomes. By contrast, executives’ values have received very little attention in empirical research (exceptions include Agle, Mitchell, and Sonnenfeld, 1999; Simsek et al., 2005). Our study begins to fill this gap by introducing the construct of political ideology (political conservatism vs. liberalism) as a reflection of CEOs’ values and by demonstrating its influence on executive decision making in an arena (CSR) in which CEOs’ values can be expected to matter greatly. Our findings serve to reinforce the main tenet of upper echelons theory: executives inject their personal biases into their strategic decisions and leadership behaviors. When faced with a given set of contextual conditions, CEOs of differing stripes, including differing values orientations, tend to pursue pathways that suit their personal inclinations.

Notably, we introduce a novel measure of political ideology as an indicator of executives’ values. Theorists have commented, at least for decades (Andrews, 1971), on the importance of executives’ values, but empirical research has been exceedingly sparse, no doubt because of the great challenges in developing generalizable, ex ante indicators of executives’ tastes. Our donation-based measure of political ideology is based on concrete, transparent behaviors, a feature that is especially noteworthy because executives’ values are typically thought of as relatively opaque and out of view (compared with their other executive attributes). We hope that others will use this measure to further advance research on the role of executives’ values.

Our study additionally provides new insights into the antecedents of CSR practices. In demonstrating that a CEO’s political ideology is manifested in a company’s CSR profiles and that a CEO’s power amplifies this relationship, the study highlights the broader importance of focusing on within-firm, especially managerial explanations of CSR. The preponderance of research has examined contextual and institutional drivers of CSR, yielding substantial but incomplete insights (Bansal and Roth, 2000; Sen, Gürhan-Canli, and Morwitz, 2001). Only recently have scholars begun to consider that CSR is a volitional managerial choice that some organizations pursue, while others—even those facing the same contextual conditions—do not (Deckop, Merriman, and Gupta, 2006; Waldman, Siegel, and Javidan, 2006). Scholars could consider a host of managerial and firm attributes as explanations for CSR practices, including ownership, board, workforce, and, as we have emphasized, executives’ characteristics.

Not only did we find that CEOs’ ideology has a main effect on CSR (which, again, is amplified by CEO power), but we also hypothesized and found that politically liberal CEOs, relative to conservative peers, tend to be relatively unresponsive to their firms’ performance levels when advancing CSR; in line with their personal values, they emphasized CSR even when company performance was poor. This is intriguing evidence of executives’ values prevailing over contextual conditions in corporate decision making. Conservative CEOs, by contrast, were more sensitive to current performance levels, especially curtailing CSR initiatives when times were poor. This latter result suggests that conservative CEOs view CSR initiatives as optional acts of corporate citizenship that can be selectively undertaken as financial conditions permit. Liberal CEOs appear to be more unconditional supporters of CSR, whereas conservative CEOs are “fair weather supporters,” who advance CSR when they believe they can spare the resources to do so.

In line with our theorizing and our use of net KLD scores, we expected liberal CEOs to focus on both sides of the CSR ledger—increasing strengths and decreasing concerns—but in a supplementary analysis, we decomposed the KLD scores to explore whether liberal CEOs might be more attentive to one side of the ledger than the other. The results indicated that CEOs’ political ideology was significantly associated with CSR concerns, but not significantly associated with CSR strengths (although the latter result was in the expected direction). This stronger result for CSR concerns suggests that liberal and conservative CEOs diverge more in their attention to “doing no harm” than in their emphasis on “doing good.” It is beyond our scope to consider such asymmetries at length, but it appears that liberal CEOs are particularly steadfast about minimizing or eliminating corporate misdeeds.

Our corroborative analysis on corporate PAC contributions offers insights for multiple disciplines, including management and political science. Corporate PAC contributions, along with lobbying, are among the most important political activities companies can engage in (Hillman, Keim, and Schuler, 2004). Previous literature, however, has focused primarily on whether corporate PAC contributions are beneficial or harmful to companies (Dean, Vryza, and Fryxell, 1998; Aggarwal, Meschke, and Wang, 2012), with far less attention to the antecedents of such behaviors. By investigating the determinants of PAC contributions, especially from an executive decision perspective, our corroborative study suggests a new lens for the study of corporate political activities.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: As with any empirical project, ours has limitations, which in turn suggest various refinements and extensions. First, our measure of CEO political ideology is inevitably an imprecise gauge of a complex psychological construct. We believe our index, based on political donation records, yields a generally meaningful indicator of executives’ values orientations, and our validation effort was supportive, but further work might improve on our index or use additional data sources, possibly including CEOs’ speeches or interviews, surveys, or media accounts.

One possible way to refine the index would be to add precision about how liberal or conservative donation recipients are. For a subsample of 30 of our CEOs, we conducted an experiment based on the NOMINATE scores developed by Poole and Rosenthal (1984), which gauge the ideology of incumbent politicians. Although intuitively promising, these scores are available only for incumbent congressional candidates, not party committees, party-affiliated PACS, or non-incumbent candidates (all of which were included in our index). Thus these scores could only be applied to a small subset of recipients (under 30 percent); as such, the refined measures were extremely highly correlated (> .92) with our original ideology index. In future work, however, we strongly believe that any measure of political ideology should include donations to parties and PACS, as these are less likely to be driven by personal ties than are donations to candidates.

Our focus strictly on CEOs can also be considered a limitation. Corporate decision making is a shared activity (Hambrick and Mason, 1984), so future research might fruitfully consider how the political ideologies of entire top management teams (TMTs), as well as those of boards of directors, influence CSR practices and other organizational outcomes. It might be especially interesting to examine how the homogeneity of political orientations among corporate elites—say, when an entire TMT is highly liberal—amplifies the findings we have presented here.

As an archival study, our project does not shed light on the actual psychological processes by which CEOs’ ideologies are converted into concrete business decisions. Based on England’s (1967) framework, we have surmised that some combination of behavior channeling and perceptual filtering is at work, but we have not been able to distinguish these two mechanisms empirically. Further research might use different methodologies, perhaps including controlled laboratory experiments or content analysis of CEOs’ speeches, to tease apart the distinct conduits through which individuals’ values affect complex choices.

We also acknowledge that undetected endogeneity may exist in the relationship between CEOs’ political ideology and CSR practices. It is possible that CEOs do not volitionally act on their ideologies, as we have argued, but instead are selected because their ideologies, explicitly or implicitly, somehow fit the task at hand. We have gone to lengths to address this alternative possibility: showing that the link between CEO ideology and CSR is amplified by a CEO’s relative power; showing that CEO ideology is also manifested in a distinctly different organizational outcome, corporate PAC allocations; showing that scandal-plagued companies do not disproportionately appoint liberal (or conservative) CEOs; and showing that a multivariable endogeneity control does not alter our results. Still, future research might improve on our tests for endogeneity; at a minimum, researchers need to bear in mind that executives’ attributes are not randomly distributed across firms or situations.

sec.title: Future Research on Executives’ Political Ideologies
sec.p: By highlighting the concept of executives’ political ideology, our project suggests a host of additional research avenues. Under the rubric of upper echelons theory, we expect that executives’ political ideologies might be manifested in an array of organizational attributes, well beyond CSR practices and PAC spending. For example, CEOs’ political orientations might show up in organizational structures and systems. As an outgrowth of their belief in egalitarianism, perhaps highly liberal CEOs (relative to conservative CEOs) install flatter organizational structures, welcome more bottom-up communication, extend stock options and profit-sharing to more employees, and minimize the pay-gap between themselves and their TMT members and other employees.

It also would be interesting to study how the political liberalism of CEOs, or of entire TMTs, influences team dynamics (e.g., Simsek et al., 2005). For instance, ideological homogeneity among TMT members might engender cognitive homogeneity and/or social integration. Moreover, interactions between CEOs and their boards could be considered. Will CEOs receive more support if they share the same political views as powerful members of their boards?

By showing that CEOs inject their values into their decisions, our study also raises questions of interest to agency theorists. According to agency theory, CEOs should be monitored and/or given incentives to induce them to make decisions on behalf of shareholders; without proper governance mechanisms, CEOs will pursue their personal interests at the expense of owners’ wealth (Rediker and Seth, 1995). Our research finds that CEOs make CSR decisions based in part on their values and, more specifically, based on their political ideologies. So should boards be concerned? Should they be looking for governance mechanisms (e.g., compensation arrangements) to offset these effects? When a CEO injects his or her values into decisions about CSR, is that good or bad? On one hand, boards may view liberal CEOs unfavorably for injecting their personal beliefs into their decisions about CSR (especially boards composed of conservatives who are skeptical about the benefits of CSR) (Jensen, 2002). On the other hand, given the empirical evidence of a positive association between CSR and corporate financial performance (Orlitzky, Schmidt, and Rynes, 2003), perhaps it is conservative CEOs who should be scrutinized for not advancing CSR, as failure to do so may harm the company’s performance.

Future research might fruitfully examine the interactive effects of CEOs’ political ideology and CSR initiatives on performance. Which is more helpful (or harmful) to company performance, heavy emphasis on CSR by liberal CEOs or heavy emphasis on CSR by conservative CEOs? On the one hand, when liberal CEOs emphasize CSR, they may do so in a way that serves non-owners, at the expense of owners; and when conservative CEOs emphasize CSR, they do so in a way designed to jointly serve both owners and other stakeholders. But a contrary scenario also can be envisioned: when liberal CEOs emphasize CSR, they do so as a central, deliberate aspect of their business strategy, with economic payoffs following; when conservative CEOs emphasize CSR, it is for cosmetic or ceremonial reasons, perhaps as a way to enhance their stature as corporate citizens, with little or no economic payoff accruing to the firm (e.g., Surroca and Tribó, 2008). In short, a host of questions about the effects of CEOs’ ideology, CSR, and their interactions, on performance could be explored.

At the more macro level, one can envision that CEOs’ political ideologies and other values might greatly influence extra-firm associations and affiliations. To the extent that CEOs have strong political ideologies, and strongly identify with those convictions, such beliefs will steer them to like-minded others, influencing their choices of external board seats, civic and philanthropic activities, and participation in business organizations, as well as their recruitment of outside directors. Political ideology might be an important unexplored dimension for considering homophily among corporate elites.

At the most macro level, the political ideologies of business leaders can be expected to influence public policies. Given that corporate CEOs can claim to be responsible for substantial economic resources, including jobs, and given that they can readily form networks and assemble microphones for getting their voices heard, their personal ideologies might affect public policies in multiple domains, including defense, health, education, immigration, and economics. Moreover, to the extent that CEOs exert political influence in support of their personal beliefs, rather than strictly adhering to their corporate agendas, one can envision that CEOs’ ideologies might—at the margin, at least—affect public policies that are of only tangential relevance or even orthogonal to their companies’ particular priorities.

bio.title: Authors’ Biographies
bio.p: M. K. Chin is a Ph.D. student of management at the Smeal College of Business, the Pennsylvania State University, 426B Business Building, University Park, PA 16802 (e-mail: mchin@psu.edu). His current research interests include the effects of top executives’ values and political ideologies on strategic decision-making processes and organizational outcomes. He received his M.S. in strategy and international management from Seoul National University.

Donald C. Hambrick is Evan Pugh Professor and Smeal Chaired Professor of Management at the Smeal College of Business, the Pennsylvania State University, 414 Business Building, University Park, PA 16802 (e-mail: dhambrick@psu.edu). His recent research focuses primarily on the study of top executives and their effects on strategy and performance. He holds an M.B.A. in marketing and planning/control from Harvard University and a Ph.D. in organizational strategy and policy from the Pennsylvania State University.

Linda K. Treviño is Distinguished Professor of Organizational Behavior and Ethics at the Smeal College of Business, the Pennsylvania State University, 402 Business Building, University Park, PA 16802 (e-mail: ltrevino@psu.edu). Her current research interests are in organizational ethics, including ethical decision making, ethical leadership, ethical behavior in organizational contexts, performance management systems, and values. She received her Ph.D. in management from Texas A&M University.
